author: Tucupita
title: Mérida se perfila como una ciudad sostenible a través del reciclaje
text:
Cortesía
En aras de un aprovechamiento completo de los recursos existentes, la reutilización de desechos sólidos representa una oportunidad para el crecimiento de una ciudad como Mérida que apunta a ser sostenible.
Por: Corresponsalía lapatilla.com
En este sentido, Pedro Fernández, coordinador de Médicos Unidos Venezuela, capítulo Mérida, quien además trabaja en proyectos sobre agua y sostenibilidad ambiental como parte de los programas que orientan desde esta ONG, aseveró que es necesario crear conciencia en los recursos que todos los ciudadanos pueden aprovechar para construir una mejor ciudad, Mérida sigue siendo un ejemplo para hacerlo realidad.
Fernández señaló que ” tenemos que enfrentar una realidad donde no sólo basta con la recolección, sino que la última fase que es la reutilización, se tome en cuenta, así como el reciclaje de los desechos sólidos. Estos pueden ser muy útiles para lograr herramientas que sostengan la producción de nuevos recursos”, afirmó.
La implementación de las 3 R “Reducir, Reutilizar y Reciclar”, debe empezar por la educación en las escuelas, implementando planes de interés colectivo en las diferentes etapas escolares, que involucren además a toda la comunidad.
Resaltó la importancia de crear consciencia en la sociedad sobre el impacto negativo de la acción del hombre sobre el medio ambiente.
Añadió que “diseñando y aplicando planes que permitan ser sostenibles y perduren en el tiempo, se puede generar un impacto positivo a mediano y largo plazo sobre la ciudad”.
También indicó que un área importante a considerar para lograr la consolidación de una ciudad sostenible, es la necesidad de pensar en nuevas formas de implementar el transporte a través de alternativas no contaminantes como, por ejemplo, las ciclovías y otros que no interfieran en la conservación del medio ambiente.
Asimismo, aseguró que todo esto es con el fin de ir educando a la población para garantizar una mejor calidad de vida, aprovechando cada recurso con los que cuenta la ciudad de Mérida.
Recordó que en Mérida se implementó la instalación de un nuevo sistema de transporte masivo hace más de 15 años y que contaba con unidades de transporte que se desplazaban por un canal exclusivo utilizando energía eléctrica.
Sin embargo, a raíz de los graves problemas que durante los últimos años ha venido enfrentando el sistema eléctrico, prácticamente obligó a desechar la idea original de funcionamiento del sistema utilizando energía limpia y ahora los autobuses tipo Yutong que integran el sistema se movilizan con gasoil, dejando de ser un sistema que opera con energía limpia y no contaminante.

author: Taylor Richardson NonStop Local Multimedia Journalist
title: Montana Climate Office sees record-low snowpack across Western Montana | Missoula News | montanarightnow.com
text: MISSOULA, Mont. - The Montana Climate Office (MCO) continues to see record-low snowpack across many watersheds in Western Montana which could lead to limited water resources in the summer. The MCO is based at the University of Montana in the W.A. Franke College of Forestry and Conservation. It reports daily drought conditions across the Treasure State and its data is used by the Montana Drought and Water Supply Monitoring Committee to help prepare for the summer months. Its current findings are showing some of the lowest snowpack projections since they started collecting data in 2003. "We're seeing snowpack that is 50% to 60% of normal [snowpack]. But in many cases, that is the lowest on record," said Kyle Bocinsky, the MCO Director of Climate Extension. The basins experiencing the most significant snowpack deficits include the Blackfoot, Middle and South Forks of the Flathead, and Sun and Smith River basins. Stuart Mountain by Missoula currently has a bottom two percentile in snow water equivalent levels in 2024 . Cooper Camp nearby Lincoln is currently projected to have a bottom five percentile in snow water equivalent this year as well. The lack of snowpack could lead to less water for local agriculture, and early closures for recreation and fishing in the summer if the snowpack melts quickly. "If it all melts at once, that would be bad and lead to even more drastic water availability issues going into the summer. If we have cold temperatures and that can sort of keep that snowpack lingering on into the season, that will help ameliorate some of those concerns," Bocinsky explained. Bocinsky believes that the areas in western Montana would need abnormal amounts of snow and precipitation over the next four weeks to recover from this dry winter. To learn more about the MCO's up-to-data drought conditions, please visit MCO's website.

organizations.name: montana drought and water supply monitoring committee

author: marketing@menafn.com (MENAFN)
title: China defies America's AI hegemony
text:
403
Sorry!!
Error! We're sorry, but the page you were looking for doesn't exist.
China defies America’s AI hegemony
(
China has emerged as both a powerhouse of AI innovation and a key architect of AI governance. Its development model—low cost, high performance, and open source—offers a stark contrast to Western strategies built on proprietary systems and competitive containment.
Beijing’s ambitions are rooted in long-term planning. Its 2017 New Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan set a goal of becoming the world’s AI leader by 2030, with the sector projected to reach $1.4 trillion in value. AI is seen as vital to counter demographic challenges such as an aging population and slower growth, while pushing China toward a more advanced, innovation-driven economy.
The country’s AI strategy is based on four pillars: data, energy, computing power, and skilled talent. China already leads in three—its massive population generates unparalleled data, its energy sector is growing rapidly, and it has a highly trained STEM workforce. Computing hardware remains its main vulnerability due to Western export restrictions, but Beijing is investing heavily to achieve self-sufficiency.
The US has sought to limit China’s progress by blocking access to advanced chips. In July 2025, the Trump administration introduced Winning the Race: America’s AI Action Plan, focusing on preserving US dominance through technological and policy advantages. The plan promotes export restrictions on AI tools and the suppression of Chinese AI models, reflecting what critics describe as a zero-sum approach that prioritizes control over collaborative global progress.
MENAFN) The global artificial intelligence landscape has reached a turning point, with China rapidly expanding its AI capabilities and influence since 2023 as part of its broader ambition to shape a new world order. AI is becoming the driving force of a new wave of scientific and industrial transformation, and Beijing is confident that the technology can generate lasting value.China has emerged as both a powerhouse of AI innovation and a key architect of AI governance. Its development model—low cost, high performance, and open source—offers a stark contrast to Western strategies built on proprietary systems and competitive containment.
Beijing’s ambitions are rooted in long-term planning. Its 2017 New Generation Artificial Intelligence Development Plan set a goal of becoming the world’s AI leader by 2030, with the sector projected to reach $1.4 trillion in value. AI is seen as vital to counter demographic challenges such as an aging population and slower growth, while pushing China toward a more advanced, innovation-driven economy.
The country’s AI strategy is based on four pillars: data, energy, computing power, and skilled talent. China already leads in three—its massive population generates unparalleled data, its energy sector is growing rapidly, and it has a highly trained STEM workforce. Computing hardware remains its main vulnerability due to Western export restrictions, but Beijing is investing heavily to achieve self-sufficiency.
The US has sought to limit China’s progress by blocking access to advanced chips. In July 2025, the Trump administration introduced Winning the Race: America’s AI Action Plan, focusing on preserving US dominance through technological and policy advantages. The plan promotes export restrictions on AI tools and the suppression of Chinese AI models, reflecting what critics describe as a zero-sum approach that prioritizes control over collaborative global progress.
